story: Officials are using the value to decide when to ease lockdown measures and often refer to it in the Covid- press briefings.R, or R nought, refers to the average number of people that one infected person can expect to pass the coronavirus on to.Scientists use it to predict how far and how fast a disease will spread - and the number can inform policy decisions about how to contain an outbreak.For example,a virus has an R of three, it means that each sick person will pass the disease on to three more people -no containment measures are introduced.Its also worth pointing out that the R is a measure of how infectious a disease is, but not how deadly.If the R rate of a disease is one or above, it will spread exponentially, infecting more and more people.Therefore, being below R is key because it means the virus will likely peter out.Scientists work backwards to estimate the R rate, as we can’t know the exact moment people are infected.A range of data is used, such as ICU admissions, hospital admissions, deaths and positive tests.It takes two to three weeks for changes in the R rate to be shown in this data, due to the time gap between infection and the need for treatment.The World Health Organisationestimated at the beginning of March that the coronavirus R rate stood between  and . - meaning the spread of the virus could snowball, with each infected person infecting between two and three others.Thanks to the lockdown and the social distancing measures that have been in place, the UK is now below that.In May, the R rate crept up, but it is thought that this is due to the outbreaks of the virus in care homes.In comparison, the R rate of the seasonal flu is estimated to be roughly ., while for the highly infectious measles its between  and .Despite this, these figures are not set in stone because a given pathogens R value is constantly changing, as behaviour changes or immunity develops.Jonathan Ball, professor of molecular virology at the University of Nottingham, told The : R is an indication of how much an infectious virus will spread in a population, and ious things impact that value.The susceptibility, size and density of the population that the infection is introduced into matters, as well as the infectiousness of the virus itself.Predictions of the R for Covid- are currently ied because no one knows exactly how many people have been infected in total.According to modelling published by Imperial College London, the R value stood somewhere between  and . in Europe before lockdowns came into effect.To keep the Covid- epidemic declining, R needs to be less than one.As of June , the R rate in the UK was . - .. title: opening pubs but not schools doesnt add up
story: PRAISE the Lord – the decision is made. You can now at last be within ft in of someone outside your immediate household! What’s more, from July , you will be able to eat in restaurants, have a drink and, of course, continue shopping.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesWhat you won’t be able to do, unless you are very fortunate, is to get your children into school, which says something about our national priorities. Make no mistake about it, this is a “national emergency”. Education should have the upfront priority that we rightly give the NHS and saving our economy. The failure since the beginning of March to plan ahead for getting all schools and all youngsters back into the classroom has been reprehensible.I say all schools because the majority have been open for the children of key workers and for children designated as vulnerable.Many teachers have been doing a first-class job trying to keep in touch with children at home, providing them with online tuition, homework and marking. But there is still time to mobilise all the necessary resources to make it possible to get children back to school for at least a couple of weeks before the end of this term.Yes, it would involve finding extra premises for schools with inadequate space. Yes, we would have to appeal to teachers who have recently retired to come back for perhaps a few hours a week. Yes, we would need to employ supply teachers.In addition we could use university students, who won’t be finding summer jobs any time soon, to assist.Of course, we don’t have that reliable summer weather that will allow teaching outside on a regular basis, butDenmark can place many lessons in an outside setting, we can.If the French, Lord help us, can get their schools mobilised and back to full operation, we can. Their trade unions are far more bolshy than ours, and teachers regrettably much less well paid.So we need a combination of creativity, imagination and drive to get pupils back. We need to rebuild the confidence of parents and staff that they are highly unlikely to contract the virus from the children, or of the children passing it on to each other.That way, we can have ironed out the glitches and be ready in September to be absolutely on the ball. Small group tutoring for recovery programmes, mentoring not just organised centrally, but co-ordinated locally.For anyone who doesn’t believe that two or three weeks matter in terms of education, when children have been out of school since the middle of March, then think again. This is about equality, narrowing the gap between the haves and have-nots, and opening a window on the world. But it is also more than that. It’s a place of social interaction, of well-being and of safety. Don’t take my word for it. Take the word of the Royal College of Paediatricians, the people whose whole le is spent on the well-being of children. They are very clear: Schools must , children need each other as well as their teachers.The recognition of the importance of schools was something I was proud to oversee in , when the incoming government’s priority slogan was, “education, education, education”.Don’t get me wrong. The belated announcement last week of a one per cent uplt for all schools and a £million pot for an online recovery programme is extremely welcome. A pity, therefore, that in making a really great announcement, the Government managed not to put any money aside for the  to -year-olds in further education, who are surely the target group we would want to be helping the most.So, thank you to all those who have done everything they can to keep the wheels on the cart over the past dficult three and a half months. But now we need both national leadership and local organisation. To use an old adage, we need to think national but we need to act local. Education trusts, local authorities, teachers’ unions and all those committed to the future of this nation should want to come together to make it work.In the next ten days, while the Government thinks about its advice, others can get on with the job. Take what is working best and spread it.What can work in France or Denmark or Germany can certainly work here. We are not out of the woods yet, but we can take logical, rational and brave decisions. That is what leadership is all about.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: harry shaped hole happy royal family
story: To the rest of us, it’s a charming exception to the more formal royal photos of old.But how was it received by the person who’s so obviously missing from this image of paternal closeness . . .  Prince Harry Since a spokesman confirmed that the Duke and Duchess of Sussex would be inactive on their @sussexroyal Instagram account from Aprilthere’s no way of knowing whether Harry would have publicly thanked his father last Sunday or , indeed, he has done so in private.But given that he’s reportedly homesick for the UK, this photo — taken in December — must have prompted a visceral longing for home. How could it not The sense of countryside and fresh air it evokes, the tweed caps, the fingerless mittens, the ornate walking stick . . .  just the innate Britishness of it all. Such a far cry from the smog, red carpets, bling and supercars of LA.And then, of course, it’s a reminder of the people he’s known since birth.Those who, unlike the “mwah mwah”, showbiz crowd, love him for who, rather than what, he is.Whichever way you view his behaviour of late, it’s undeniable that there is a huge, Harry-shaped hole in this image of family togetherness.Of course, there are Zoom meetings to be had and, post-lockdown, the occasional visit to be made. But it’s never quite the same.And therein lies the rub when you marry someone from another country.At first your initial attraction and then love for each other transcends geographical or cultural dferences.But when children come along and you’re required to stay in one place, inevitably one of you has to give up more than the other.Meghan tried it, albeit for a very short time, and now Harry is the one living thousands of miles away from his family and the only le he’s ever known.He made the decision to step down as a senior royal and decamp to the US for the sake of his new family — Meghan and Archie — but that doesn’t make it any less tough to see the old one ticking over nicely without him.A couple of years ago, I was in a central London restaurant with a group of other married couples and, much to the annoyance of we wives, the husbands couldn’t take their eyes off a woman sitting at the bar.Wearing the shortest of dresses, her legs were encircled around the object of her affections and her tongue made frequent visits to his ear.I recognised the man as actor Stephen Campbell Moore, ex-husband of The Crown star Claire Foy, and his obviously smitten companion as Sophie Cookson, who played Christine Keeler in last year’s BBC drama about the Profumo scandal.Fast forward to lockdown and this photo, suggests the couple may now be expecting their first child.The fond arrival of which will mean a heavy-hearted goodbye to those late-night, lust-filled liaisons that had the rest of us drooling with envy.Kaiser Chiefs frontman Ricky Wilson says he amuses himself by lying in interviews then changing his Wikipedia page to match his inventions.It reminds me of my stint as a royal correspondent when, after days of being on the road together, we would challenge each other to use silly names in stories.Hence, “Toby Lerone” was quoted in an article filed from the royals’ favourite ski resort in Switzerland, and in another story to do with Italy, “Sam Buca” made an appearance.Daft, I know, but it amused usno one .Mr Pendragon, who refuses to pay to park, says they stopped him from leaving his car on nearby roads.Shouldn’t he have been on horseback Bored by St Tropez, billionaires are reportedly snapping up “expedition yachts” that will take them to more adventurous corners of the globe.The one owned by US billionaire Ray Dalio has three deep-ing submersibles, and converted former Soviet spy boat Olivia is currently on the market for £million.Back home, lock-down quarantine rules have forced a  per cent rise in multi-millionaire Brits splashing their cash on vast private pools.Meanwhile, the rest of us will make do with a boat in the bath and a paddling pool.Sarah Ferguson – aka Prince Andrew’s ex we – is building up quite a following on her YouTube channel, where she reads children’s books such as The Wonky Donkey and Little Red Riding Hood while wearing fancy dress.Her success is no surprise, because on the many occasions I’ve seen her at charity events, she always connects brilliantly with the children in attendance.But personally, I can’t wait for her to get round to the critically acclaimed Idan Hadari book about a boy who wants to be famous.It’s called Andrew’s Claim To Fame.Or, in the Duke of York’s case, should that be infamy Yep. She now looks about .When -year-old Khairi Saadallah started his alleged kne rampage in a Reading park, a young, off-duty police officer ran towards the danger and rugby tackled him to the ground.It was a selfless act of bravery that, according to sources, saved “many more people dying”.Meanwhile, a judge has praised the bravery of PC Andrew Harper, who died after being dragged along by a car as he chased some thieves.Both of these are salutary reminders that, while every police force in the world has a few bad apples, the majority of those working in law enforcement are undeniably courageous people doing a tough job that most of us would shy away from.The latest money-making exercise candle from Gwyneth Paltrow is called This Smells Like My Orgasm.Which, as you ask, is “tart grapefruit, neroli, and ripe cassis berries blended with gunpowder tea and Turkish rose absolutes”. Er, right.Like its highly successful predecessor This Smells Like My Vagina candle – which, for the blissfully unaware, is “geranium, citrusy bergamot, and cedar absolutes juxtaposed with Damask rose and ambrette seed” – it costs£.Clearly, she’s a sales genius who could flog underwear to a nudist, but one suspects any attempt to branch out with a, to put it politely, Smells Like My Winkle range might prove a tougher sell.Hmmm. While the new name — Lost The Pot Noodle — is inspired, one notes that it now requires the consumer to put the ingredients in a mug or make it in a pan on the stove.As any self-respecting, Olympically idle student will tell you, a clean mug is a rarer sighting than an eclipse and, as for a pan, eventhey own one it will be housing enough penicillin growth to solve America’s recent shortage.So, memo to Unilever: Don’t phase out the original just yet.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: new study reveals eight in ten brits feel they settled for their partner
story: A study of , adults found a ‘guess that will do’ approach has been adopted because they either haven’t been able to afford better, or get what they really want. Incredibly,  per cent of adults have found themselves in a relationship with someone they didn’t think was ‘the one’ – with  per cent doing so because they didn’t want to be left on the shelf and  per cent worrying they’d never find love.And seven in ten adults have at some point accepted a salary which was far from ideal, with a fth feeling there wasn’t room for negotiation and one quarter hoping a pay rise might happen in the future.Of those polled,  per cent have also accepted a job they didn’t want, largely because they couldn’t find anything better.A spokeswoman for Lottoland, which carried out the research in connection with their new Lotto Plus Multiple Millionaires Bonus draw, said: “We know that people often want more out of le, and as such strive to do better, but the findings do indicate an acceptance that things can’t always be perfect.“However, there should be some areas of le where you don’t settle for second best.It is human nature to want more – more fun, more spontaneity, and more choice – and that’s why we’re introducing more choice and more opportunities for our own customers.”The study also found a house, friendships, and a car are among the other le changing things adults have settled for, when they really didn’t want to.Almost two third of adults have ended up moving into a house which wasn’t their dream home, with money the chief factor.And  per cent have found themselves in unhealthy friendships, with confidence cited as the main reason for not pursuing alternative relationships.But when it comes to settling in le, not all decisions are le changing.Nearly four in  adults have had to settle on a supermarket’s own brand of food over something posher, while  per cent have made do with a cheap restaurant rather than opting for fine dining.Choosing a slice of cake smaller than one would like, and deciding on the house wine over something a little more refined also feature in the top  list.Furniture for the home, haircuts, shoes and gts are also among the things Brits have chosen, despite wanting better.It also emerged three in  have settled for the price of something rather than negotiating, and  per cent have resigned themselves to working long hours instead of meeting up with friends.. Salary. Job. Dream house. Car. Friendships. Partner. Supermarkets own food instead of branded. A cheaper restaurant over fine dining. Staying at home for the evening instead of going out with. Clothing brands. The price of something rather than negotiating. A gt for someone. Mobile phone   smart phone. Area you live in. House wine instead of the higher cost option. A self-catered holiday over a luxurious all inclusive. Furniture. Haircut. Shoes. Working longer hours instead of spending time with friends. Having a small slice of cake instead of a massive one. Clothes a size larger than youd like to be buying. Coffee - getting instant instead of the good stuff. TV. Decor. The cost of utility bills. Cheap beers. Who to socialise with. Handbags. Fitness gear Holidays, the area to live in, smart phones, and coffee also feature in the list as those things where sometimes, second best will have to do.But researchers from OnePoll found two thirds of those polled DO want more out of le, and the same percentage say the older they get, the less likely they are to settle for anything less than perfect.Four in  adults will only settle on somethingthey really don’t have a choice, and  per cent said money is always the decisive factor.Being too relaxed, lacking confidence, and wanting to go with the flow are also reasons why Brits don’t push to get what they want all the time.Butthey had the choice and felt able,  per cent would like to improve their financial situation, while  per cent want a better salary.One fth of adults would like to improve their relationships, and one third want to live somewhere nicer both in terms of house, and location.A spokeswoman for Lottoland added: “As a nation we’re go-getters, and striving to do better is part of who we are.Lottoland wants to mirror that by offering playing more chances to win, more flexibility and more enjoyment along the way.“In the spirit of offering more, we’re launching a special promotion for Lotto Plus players – the Multiple Millionaires Bonus Draw. a x Volvo XC Hybrid - in a bid to woo would-be ticket-buyers.Dale lives at the property in Ossett, West Yorks, we Katherine and their four kids, but hasnt been able to sell his property during the pandemic.And he said he quickly became fed up with estate agents.“There’s only been one viewing in the past month, so I thought it wasn’t looking good, he said,“You’ve got to think outside the box with these things.”Competitors can buy as many of the , tickets as they want.The Tate family had hoped for a quick sale as they plan to move to Australia at the end of the year.Dale, who works as an engineer, said: People havent got anything to lose really - story: The Committee requested the Pentagon release all data collected on unidentied aerial phenomenon and intrusions over restricted US airspace.The call for unidentied aerial phenomena review is a big win for those who seek more transparency on what the government knows about UFOs.“Assuming the report is properly prepared and delivered, there is no telling what the impacts could be, Christopher Mellon, a former top Pentagon intelligence official and Senate staffer who has pressed for more research on the topic, told Politico. Melon continued: That could range from revealing an unknown threat or military vulnerability to there have been probes visiting our planet, or anything in between.The  annual intelligence authorization bill, which still needs to be passed by the full Senate, was submitted by acting Intelligence Committee chairman Sen. Macro Rubio and others on June , . The submission raised concerns that the government has not devoted the appropriate amount of resources to UAP.The Committee remains concerned that there is no unied, comprehensive process within the federal government for collecting and analyzing intelligence on unidentied aerial phenomena, despite the potential threat, the committee states in its report on the bill.The bill orders the Director of National Intelligence to produce a thorough report with relevant agencies, including the FBI and the Office of Naval Intelligence. The unclassied report, which may include a classied annex, will contain details about a series of encounters with UAP and advanced aerial threats. Some of those encounters may not be with extraterrestrials, but instead adversaries of America testing the nations defenses.What’s more, the report must detail what information has been previously gathered on UAPs, how the data is collected and published, and what risks UFOs could pose.In April, the Pentagon declassied and released three videos taken by US Navy pilots showing mid-air encounters with what appeared to be UFOs.One of the videos was reportedly shot in November  and the other two in January . But exactly how much will be revealed in the new report depends on what the Pentagon deems unclassied.If the bill passes, the Pentagon will have  days to submit the report to Congress.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: russian oligarch 360m superyacht docks south of france
story: Andrey Melnichenko wowed onlookers as he pulled his enormous ft-long futuristic vessel with luxurious on-board pool and extravagant lounge decks into port. The impressive vessel, which comes complete with eight decks and masts that are almost ft tall, is the ninth largest yacht in the world and took four years to build.The luxury yacht features multiple dining rooms and several balconies which stylishly open up on the side of the hull.The yacht is powered by a hybrid diesel-electric package with controllable pitch propellers.Up to  lucky guests can be accommodated on the mega-boat, hosted by a crew of , according to reports.Aside from the opulent lounge, the superyacht boasts floor-to-ceiling windows, a combination of leather and wood furniture and a rotating bed.It also has free-floating spiral staircases and three masts that are taller than Big Ben and stretch up from the extraordinary wedge-shaped boat hull.One of the masts is accessible from the inside, but the crew dont need to climb them – the boat’s sails unfurl at the touch of a button.The masts are technical masterpieces, and can rotate to make the most of the wind when out at sea.The boat was also designed with bomb-proof glass windows and an owners cabin which is larger than most apartments in London or New York.The high-gloss ship is able to whir across the waves at speeds of up to .knots .The ship also boasts a garage fit for four vehicles and a submarine, as well as a helipad on the bow.Melnichenko named his superyacht A because in order for the vessel to be listed first in shipping registers.The total sail area is equal to that of half a football pitch, with two double-decker buses able to be hung from the masts.The Russian industrialists newest yacht also includes rotating masts that were built by Magma Strustures at Trafalgar Wharf, Portsmouth.The Russian billionaire is notorious for his extravagant lestyle.Alongside his two astonishing superyachts, the billionaire owns a customised Boeing  private jet, a villa in the French Riviera, a penthouse in New York and an estate near Ascot, England. He married his model we Aleksandra in an opulent ceremony in the South of France with singers Whitney Houston and Christina Aguilera leading the after-party.Melnichenko, , is also the father of a young daughter and has an estimated net worth of around £.billion, making him the th richest person in Russia and the th wealthiest person in the world.The Russian made his billions founding the fertiliser producer EuroChem, coal producer Suek, and power generator SGK. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: stay half in half out of lockdown well be happier
story: LOCKDOWN is pretty much over. The Prime Minister announced that we were at last allowed out of our Great British Hibernation.We can go to the pub, buy useless tat in shops and queue up for plaster lawn ornaments from garden centres. We can have the in-laws round to visit! Yoot!⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesBoris says that his decision was made on good scientic advice. Hmm, maybe. It is true that the infection rate for Covid has been dropping rapidly for some time. But it’s still there, still hanging around with mischief on its mind. All it takes is one person in a gathering of  or  at some pizza joint and that infection rate will be up again quickly enough.In some of the countries that have released their people from lockdown, a second spike has occurred.In Germany the famous “R” rate for infection is well above the dreaded one. South Korea and Spain have seen new outbreaks, too.But the truth is Boris didn’t have much of an option. The public is bored stf and the economy is wrecked.I suspect the decision was arrived at on those grounds, rather than strictly on the science. Everyone wants to go out and spend money. I am not sure why they do.  There were good things about lockdown — and it taught us one or two truths about ourselves.It was a pleasure to hear the birds singing, for example. A real delight to see the roads free from traffic. The skies are full of swts and swallows instead of the incessant airline flights. The quality of the air we breathe improved hugely as a result. So did the water quality of rivers and streams.We went out much, much less. As a consequence, many people saved an awful lot of money because they weren’t wasting it on buying rubbish from shops.People learned to cook — and ate home-prepared meals with their families. The truth is, in normal times, we eat out far more often than is good for us, financially or otherwise. And we shopped locally — the corner stores did a roaring trade — and less often, thus saving carbon emissions.Employers discovered that people could work from home perfectly well. Hopefully this will persuade some to scale back their offices and give people the chance to work from home.Imagine how many homes could be created from disused offices! We wouldn’t have to pave over half the country to sort out our housing crisis. Imagine cutting out the daily commute for ever!We didn’t have to hug people. Indeed, we were barred by law from hugging people. Or kissing them on the bloody cheek, like everyone in the media world does. That, by itself, was a huge bonus for me.My wish is that we take some of that stuff from lockdown and make it the new normal. Live at a quieter, gentler pace. Continue to eat at home — and support our local corner shops. Use the car less. Spend less money on a whole load of b******s we don’t really need. Use aeroplanes not at all, preferably. Right now, the Government has given us licence to go out and do stuff.Here’s my plea. Let’s do a bit less stuff than we used to. Let’s remain kind of half in and half out of lockdown. Whether Covid is still around or not. We’ll end up happier as a result.ONE thing Captain Tom showed us, as he walked around his garden as he approached the age of , is that it’s never too late to make a dference.Bob Dylan is just a young whippersnapper by Tom’s standards.But at the age of  he has just made his finest album in at least three decades, and probably more. Rough And Rowdy Ways is a joy to listen to – and I’d given up on the bloke in the s.If I ever reach  I intend to make a grime album with Rihanna. Get your orders in now.The United Nations has decided to give them to Mauritius. That’s because the islands are nearer Mauritius than they are to the UK. On that basis we could have a good claim to owning Belgium. The islands are important to the UK militarily. And we should keep them. The UN has given us deadlines to hand them over to a country that never owned them. What we should do instead is leave the crooked UN.EXCLUDED from the Government’s loosening of lockdown are Britain’s vibrant community of werewolves and vampires.“It is all very well biting someone’s neck, or ripping their lungs out while howling loudly,” a scientist advising the Government probably said. “But when they do this there is the risk that the virus could be passed on via droplets from the creature’s mouth. Or indeed paws – werewolves do not have a good record of using hand-sanitiser.”By contrast, zombies were praised for their social-distancing technique. “Whenever you see them they are always walking two metres apart with their hands outstretched and bits of flesh falling off their faces,” the same scientist probably added.A spokesman for the National Association of Lycanthropescommented: “This is typical of the prejudice we werewolves face and amounts to discrimination. Actually, I thought I had the virus a few weeks ago. Nasty cough and so on.“But I’m all right nooooowwwwwwooooo.”THE day after the woke ninnies at Warners withdrew the great Hollywood film Gone With The Wind because of “race issues”, guess what happened  Yup, it became the No bestselling film on Amazon. Better still, it reached No in the AppleiTunes chart for TV and film. Not bad for a movie made more than  years ago, huh I suppose it could have been “progressives” buying the film so that they would have something to be outraged about. Or maybe the Ku Klux Klan Film Club has a bigger membership than we thought.More likely though is that people loathe censorship. They don’t like being told what they can and can’t watch. Truth be told it hasn’t been for a good  years. And the process accelerated under Magic Grandpa and his front bench of mouth-breathing dingbats. Now it’s the well-orf who support Labour. And the poor who vote Conservative. But there aren’t enough people called Olly and Poppy in the country, which is why Labour hasn’t won an election for  years. Unless it reconnects with the people it was set up to support, the working class, it won’t win one for another few decades either.A SOCIAL media site had a big hit when it asked people to reveal things they regretted about getting married. The site, Whisper, was inundated with replies. Most were kind of: “I just wish I hadn’t married the fat bastard, full stop.”But some wished they’d had a fling with someone of the same sex first, or felt aggrieved they hadn’t checked out the in-laws first. That was quite a big issue. title: pubs reopening laws summer drinking
story: NEW laws to be rushed through within days will allow a summer of drinking in streets, car parks and other outdoor spaces to help pubs bounce back from months in lockdown.It will allow thousands more pubs, restaurants and cafes to serve customers outside by July  rather than requiring y planning applications.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe new Business and Planning Bill will also relax planning permission rules to make it easier and quicker to arrange car boot sales, summer fetes and outdoor markets.It will double the amount of time that planning permissions last for these temporary events and allow ‘temporary structures’ such as marquees and street trading stalls to stay up for up to  days.Iniduals and businesses will have greater power to use their land for temporary retail activities in a bid to inject much-needed le into local economies across England.It will also help the fight against the virus by encouraging people to be outdoors, where the risk of spreading the virus is much lower.Ministers hope it will lead to a surge in al fresco dining and drinking.Temporary chances to licensing laws will allow many more licences premises such as pubs and restaurants to sell alcohol for consumption off their premises.Customers will be able to buy their drinks from a pub and consume them where, making social distancing easier.Pubs and restaurants will be able to use car parks and terraces as dining and drinking areas - enabling customers to enjoy their drinks and food outside.Government sources said the move will given an “immediate and much-needed boost to many businesses” as they prepare to reopen on July  after  days shut during lockdown.But the Government has dropped plans to scrap Sunday Trading rules that limit the opening hours for shops after Tory rebels and Labour threatened to torpedo the whole bill.  It means the bill is likely to sail through Parliament next week - in time for the lting of lockdown measures on July .A government source said: “It’s about kickstarting this whole hospitality and retail industry beyond bricks and mortar shops over the busy summer period.“The Government will introduce new laws giving people greater freedom over how they use their land by doubling the amount of time that activities like that temporary structures can be placed on land without permission.”Meanwhile it emerged that the PM’s top aide Dominic Cummings has vowed to overhaul the civil service after concluding the Whitehall machine has been exposed by the coronavirus pandemic.The ConservativeHome website reported that he told an internal government meeting that the Cabinet Office will be stripped of powers after being found wanting during the crisis.Mr Cummings is said to have told fellow government aides: “A hard rain is coming”.Meanwhile Downing Street indicated that extra support could be offered to theatres in England which have been ordered to remain closed for live performances. The Prime Ministers official spokesman said: We are talking to the arts sector and considering ways in which we might be able to support them in addition to the unprecedented financial assistance we have already given.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: school return pupil bubble cap doubles
story: Under current rules, class numbers are capped at  and social distancing measures leave heads with a logistical nightmare requiring double the teaching space.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesBut from the autumn primary school pupils will not be required to keep apart from others in their own “protective bubble”, just stay away from other groups.One of the first schools to fully reopen in Britain has made passionate calls for others to follow suit — and urged “isive” unions to get on board.St Paul’s CofE Primary in Swanley, Kent, welcomed back nearly all of its  children on Monday thanks to shrewd social distancing and hygiene measures.The school’s chiefs put a marquee in their playing field to create extra space — and supplied portaloos and mobile hand washing facilities to keep kids safe.Dferent classes are kept apart with their own inidual entrances and exits. And eager children have ed straight back into lessons under strict social distancing rules without hassle.Thecomes in spite of teaching unions pouring scorn over moves to get all kids safely back in class by September.Headteacher Ben Hulme said tonight: “Schools like us have shown it can be done safely for both children and staff.“This is a time when unions, schools and headteachers should all be pulling together to get children back in class. To be isive makes it really dficult to get back to some safe normality.“There have been many reports about how lockdown has affected children’s mental health and emotional wellbeing — and how there’s potential for damage to be donewe don’t move quickly. That really spurred us on to get something together — and it’s working very well.“We’re really pleased to be back and I’d encourage other schools to do the samethey can.”Under the new plans, the Government aims to form “year group bubbles” in secondary schools.This would stop pupils mingling with teenagers from other year groups, while allowing classes toto their normal size.Education Secretary Gavin Williamson hailed St Paul’s safe and swt— and called on others to take “full advantage” of the chance to open again.He told The Sun: “We have given primary schools the flexibility to bring back more children — where they can do so within our protective measures — and it’s fantastic to see some schools taking full advantage of that to maximise their capacity and invite back all pupils.”Anne Longfield, the Children’s Commissioner for England, heaped praise on St Paul’s — and urged other schools to follow its lead.She said: “This is a real achievement and great to see teachers working with parents to get the whole school open safely before the summer break.”The Government originally ­pledged to get all primary schools back in action for at least a month before June . But ministers had to ditch the plans over fears that the target would not be met.Militant unions have been accused of playing politics and stopping kids ing to class, instead of putting their welfare first.Department for Education data revealed , pupils were in class last month — down from . million on a normal school day.Latest figures show approximately . million attended school last Thursday — . per cent of pupils who normally attend." rel"noreferrer noopener"Boris Johnson told MPs yesterday that education would restart fully at the start of autumn term.It was welcome news for millions of parents who have endured three months of lockdown — many juggling full-time jobs with childcare and home-schooling. Secondary schools in England have been allowed to reopen for Years ,  and  since June .Nursery and pre-school children, plus pupils in Reception, Year  and Year , started toon June .But not all schools have reopened fully. Some do not have the staff and others do not have the space.Current government guidance for schools does not require kids to socially distance within their bubble, but many schools are ignoring the advice, insisting on all pupils remaining two-metres apart.The rules planned for September would make clear that social distancing would not be required within bubbles.Instead, kids will be encouraged to limit contact with each other.Its Headmaster Ben Hulme used his imagination, created extra space on the school field and put other hygiene measures in place.Now, to the delight of parents, almost all his pupils started back on Monday. story: A disciplinary  heard PC Phillip Smallcombe, , led the cortege at funerals instead of pounding the beat.He quit South Wales Police after his cheating was discovered and has now been banned from being a police officer.Mr John Bassett, chair of the misconduct , said: He had failed to seek authorisation for this business interest and when he did, the application was not authorised.A police officer is required to declare their business interests, which Mr Smallcombe did not do until he had been involved in the running of the business for a year, and continued working after an application was submitted and not approved.Police officers are allowed outside business interests as long as they are authorised and do not conflict with police work. title: music britain collapsing covid 19
story: And now I’m scratching my head wondering how cinemas are able to welcome visitors before we’ve worked out how to listen to music together.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesLive music is vital, not just for fuelling our dreams but for the reality of our economy, too.The live music sector is expecting to suffer £million in losses this year, which is  per cent of its annual contribution to the UK economy.From arena concerts to your local pub singer, ALL live music has been silenced.But the Government doesn’t seem to be taking it seriously, with music way down the list of priorities and no date in the diary for when we will be able to go to a gig again.We can’t afford to take our music scene for granted.Since the birth of rock ’n’ roll, Britain has dominated global tastes in pop music.Part of The Beatles’ legacy is that they transformed the British record business from a cottage industry into a global phenomenon.When they signed to Parlophone, early in the Sixties, one man and his secretary ran the entire label.George Martin signed the band, produced, manufactured and promoted their early records and, over the brief course of the band’s existence, saw the whole thing go through the roof.It was comparable to the dotcom boom or internet shopping.Many now see the Rolling Stones as the greatest band to come out of that era for the way they have managed to continue playing to vast new audiences  years later.But the Sixties was just the start of it. The Seventies brought Led Zeppelin and countless rock bands, it gave us heavy metal and punk and Joy Division pretty much all at the same time.The biggest-selling album of the Eighties, Michael Jackson’s Thriller, was actually written by a bloke from Hull, while British greats as erse as Duran Duran and The Smiths ruled the waves.In the Cool Britannia of the Nineties, when Britpop was ringing out of radio networks worldwide, even American stars such as Madonna sought help from British producers such as Nellee Hooper and William Orbit.Then there were the Spice Girls. And Coldplay. Now we’ve got Ed Sheeran and Adele. And it doesn’t stop with artists. Love him or hate him, Simon Cowell’s TV programmes are another British global music phenomenon.But it’s live music where Britain really dominates today. Glastonbury should be taking place this weekend.I’ve played at just about every major festival on the planet, from Coachella in the US to Fuji Rock in Japan, but there is nowhere to touch Glastonbury.It is, quite simply, the greatest show on earth There is a massive ripple effect from Glastonbury. It sets a very high bar for the other  — that’s  — festivals that happen throughout the UK every single summer.And the same crews who build the stages, operate the sound systems, put up the fences and supply the bogs for Glasto are busy for the rest of the summer at other events.Now the independent festival sector is at risk of collapse thanks to the Covid shutdown.Last month, the Association of Independent Festivals , which represents  festivals in the UK, reported that  per cent of its members were facing costs that could ruin their businesses and . per cent were uninsured for Covid- related cancellations.Most of my time these days is spent planning and organising The Big Feastival, which was due to take place here on my farm in Oxfordshire this August Bank Holiday weekend.Of course I’m devastated it won’t be going ahead, but the really sad thing is that it looks like no one is going to hear any live music, new or old this summer.That’s a tragedy for the musicians who rely on gigging to make a living — as well as all the other people whose income relies on live music.The Musicians’ Union says its members have lost more than £million in income during the lockdown. Remember, that most musicians just scrape by at the best of times.Big stars are bigger than ever before, but they are the exception not the rule. When Adele releases another record there is a danger she will become so massive she will collapse into a black hole.But now bands need an audience to play to and also financial support, which used to come from record companies but now is hard to find.Records, or downloads, are basically free these days, so live shows are the only real way to make money.In the same way restaurants were already struggling before lockdown, many of Britain’s smaller live music venues were struggling too.So most of the places I played in the early days with Blur have already dis- appeared. They need to be able to open their doors again, as do festivals.It has to be possible to find a way. Just as with pubs, restaurants and cinemas, you could limit the number of people allowed into a venue.Perhaps more gigs could be seated to ensure social distancing. Not quite the same, but better than nothing.As far as the rest of the planet is concerned, Britain is represented pretty much by the Royal Family, football and music.We must keep our festival circuit alive and nurture new artists.That means we urgently have to find a way for music to be played to a live audience, evenit’s only a small one — so that we can keep meaning something to the rest of the world.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Reductions to the amount being spent on the scheme will start in September.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesA survey of , businesses on behalf of London-based lender MarketFinance Ltd found nearly  per cent planned job cuts.The poll also found that  per cent of companies plan to bring back up to half of their furloughed staff next month.The government s coronavirus job retention scheme was announced in March  allowing furloughed employees to claim  per cent of their wages up to £, a month. But it doesnt affect your redundancy pay rightsyou are let go from your job amid the coronavirus crisis.Your employer should still carry out a fair redundancy process.You are also entitled to appeal the decision by claiming unfair dismissal within three months of being let go.If youre made redundant after your company has gone into administration you can claim redundancy pay " href"https:www.gov.uk claim-redundancy" target"_blank" rel"nofollow noreferrer noopener"via Gov.uk. Youll get:Sadly, you wont be entitled to a payoutyouve been working for your employer for fewer than two years.There should be a period of collective consultation as well as time for inidual onesyour employer wants to make  or more employees redundant within  days or each other.The Office for National Statisticsestimates furlough costs around £billion a month.As bars, restaurants, pubs, hairdressers, cinemas and most other businesses in England are allowed to reopen on July , firms financial viability will be put to the test in a fight to survive after the lockdown. title: gyms pools could reopen next month backlash coronavirus lockdown easing plans

title: museums timed tickets gallery audi guides scrapped
story: Museums will be able to finally reopen on July  after a four-month shutdown, but visitors will have to follow one way routes under strict new guidelines.Museums have been told they will have to allocate timed tickets to reduce the number of people entering an exhibition or site at any one time. People probably wont be allowed to pop into a museum or gallery on a whim, as these tickets may need to be pre-booked, according to guidance from the Government. Venues should also put in one-way systems where possible, to limit the number of people moving in and out of dferent rooms. The guidance suggests implementing wait or stop signs in busy areas. Foyers and assembly areas will be used for queuing, which will have to be socially distanced. Interactive exhibitions could also have to be ditched - meaning audio guides to museums could be banned. If museums want to keep them in place, the rules suggest thorough cleaning and quarantining them to limit the risk of germs lingering after visitors have used them. The guidance says: Museumsnew formats for the content such as apps that can be accessed on personal devices or quarantine periods for public handsets. Internal shops and cafes will have to follow the same social distancing advice as those outside of museums and galleries - including quarantining clothes which people have tried on, taking orders via apps, and putting screens in front of counters to protect staff. Visiting museums and galleries could mean a long hike up stairs, as venues have been advised to limit the use of lts to people with limited mobility. This is because lts are small, enclosed spaces where the risk of spreading coronavirus is higher. Where it isnt possible to follow the  metre social distancing rule, staff and visitors will have to follow the one metre plus rule which means staying  metre away and using extra precautions such as face masks.While the advice doesnt make face masks mandatory in museums or galleries, it advises managers to consider bringing them in for staff where they think it is necessary. Heritage sites will also be subject to the advice and will need clear floor markings showing visitors through via a one-way-system to stop crowds forming. The guidance also advised heritage sites to put in similar pre-booking systems in place to limit being flooded with visitors. story: The marathon seven-day poll is taking place in the middle of the coronavirus crisis, and would allow Putin to serve another two terms in office, remaining in power until .Putin unleashed a political storm in January with his plan to overhaul the Russian Constitution for the first time since .The official vote is scheduled for  July, but authorities opened polling stations a week early to stop overcrowding amid the pandemic - which has seen around , new confirmed cases per day.The amendments would pave the way for Putin to rule for  more years, by allowing a sitting or a former president to run for office no matter how many terms they have previously held. It would mean the -year-old would break Josef Stalins record of  years in power. Opposition activist Alexei Navalny has said the changes will allow Putin to be president for le.Putin said they will rather ensure Russias stability.The president has not publicly confirmed plans to run again in  when his current term ends - which was given a boost by yesterdays patriotic parades for the th anniversary of victory over the Nazis.Critics are instead raising concerns about the votes legitimacy, claiming the plebiscite is a sham and that Putin intends to cling to power.They claim the vote is indeed a “veneer of democracy” on the controversial changes.Former Kremlin speechwriter-turned-political analyst Abbas Gallyamov said of the vote: “Nothing will prevent the Kremlin from getting the formal result they need.”The amendments have already been approved by both houses of parliament, the countrys Constitutional Court and were signed into law by Putin.The President has said he is confident the “absolutely majority” of Russians will approve of the changes.According to the Levada independent polling centre, % of Russians said in late May they would vote yes, and % would vote no - title: dogs pets cool heatwave tips advice
story: We have top tips plus all the information on the ailments your pet could suffer from during the UK heatwave and how to keep them fit, healthy and cool.They can – and it is recommended.There has been some discussion whether or not giving your dog ice on hot days can cause bloating in the animal, especially deep-chested large-breed dogs, but there seems to be no evidence for this and the RSPCA recommends adding ice to their water bowl.Simply pop some in your pooch’s water bowl to help the water stay fresh and cool as the cubes will help lower the temperature.Some dogs also like popsicles and ice lollies, not the human ieties as those may contain articial sweeteners and could be toxic to our four-legged friends.Try making some frozen bars just with water and some beef or chicken stock.Cats too can benefit from ice cubes in their water bowls.The experts at Battersea Dogs Home have drawn up a list to keep your beloved pooch cool and heathy as the temperature soars.Never leave dogs alone in carsIt can be fatal for them evenleft in shade with the windows open.If you do see a dog alone in a car you are advised to dial .Always remember waterWhile it is important to remember to put out water for your dog all year round it is especially important during any heatwave.Plan your walksAvoid going out during the hottest part of the day.Introduce new gamesTry to bring in new games your beloved pet can play ideally ones that dont involve too much running about.One idea could be to hide treats about the house and let your pooch snf them out.You can use treats to lure your dog into cooler areas, such as a shaded paddling pool.Regularly groom your dogRegular grooming and clipping will keep your pets fur clean and free of knots. Matted or tangled fur can trap heat.Dont forget the suncreamJust like humans, dogs can suffer from sunburnyoure not careful.Most pet stores though will stock specially formulated lotions.Protect the pawsHot surfaces like tarmac or sand can really hurt a dogs paws.The RSPCA also has some great advice for looking after your pet during the heatwave to avoid problems.If you take your dog for a walk when it’s hot, it is best to avoid the hottest parts of the day and will reduce the chances of burning their paws on the pavement or suffer from heatstroke.RSPCA pet welfare expert Dr Samantha Gaines told Your Dog: “Though many of us will be looking forward to this week’s spell of sunny, hot weather, it is really important we make sure to plan how we’ll keep our pets cool and comfortable this week.“We’ve all experienced a very challenging time with lockdown, and as measures have eased it will be tempting during the hot weather this week for us to want to spend lots of time outside with our families and take our pets, but taking our dogs out with us for walks or to the park could really put them at risk of suffering heat stroke or exhaustion.It’s really important that we take extra special care of our pets and wildle during this extremely hot weather.”Signs of heatstroke include:Fast action is neededyou suspect your dog is suffering from heatstroke.Take them to a cool, shaded area.Apply towels soaked in cold water to their head, neck and chest and let them drink water or lick an ice cube.Never place them directly into ice cold water or give them too much to drink as they may go into shock.Call your vet immediately.Make sure dogs and other pets have access to water and shaded areas.Tanks for fish, amphibians and reptiles should be kept out of direct sunlight, with regular water changes.Indoor birds and aviaries should have some shade.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. The R number was put at the centre of the governmentaposs communications about easing lockdown in May. When he reopened schools and non-essential shops, the PM told England on May : This package has been carefully designed so that we can ease the burdens of lockdown, while expecting to keep that R below one. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAnyone who wants access to a Tory politician can pay to go to a Tory fundraiser, a minister has declared. Nadhim Zahawi made the frank admission in a bizarre bid to defend his party in a row about access to the highest levels of government. The Business Minister was asked by the BBC why aposRed Wallapos Tory voters in Doncaster or Ashfield don’t have the same access as billionaire Richard Desmond. He replied: If people go to a fundraiser in their local area in Doncaster for the Conservative Party they’d be sitting next to MPs and other people in their local authority, and can interact with dferent parts of the authority. The Tories have never made any secret of the fact people can buy access to the party - but it is rare to have such a frank statement saying so. By donating £,, donors can join the Leadersapos Group to dine in private with the PM and senior ministers. The party has always insisted there is no undue influence. Acting Leader of the Liberal Democrats Ed Davey said: It is scandalous to suggest that the most appropriate way for the public to lobby Conservative MPs is to pour money into Tory party coffers. Members of Parliament are there to serve all their constituents, not just those who can write them big cheques. The Prime Minister now must show leadership. He must sack Robert Jenrick. It comes as Housing Secretary Robert Jenrick faces questions over his decision to approve a £bn housing development in London against the advice of a planning inspector. He gave Westferry Printworks, planned by billionaire Tory donor Richard Desmond, the green light on January  - hours before a council levy kicked in that would have cost the developer around £m. Itaposs since emerged Mr Desmond showed the minister a video of the scheme on his phone at a Tory fundraising dinner in November, and texted him asking him to approve it before the deadline.  On November , Mr Desmond told him we donapost want to give Marxists in Tower Hamlets council loads of doe for nothing. In an e-mail dated January , a government official said Mr Jenrick was insistent that decision issued this week ie tomorrow - as next week the viability of the scheme is impacted by the levy. Mr Desmond is not accused of wrongdoing, and Mr Jenrick has insisted that while there could have been an appearance of bias, there was no actual bias. Even so, the minister cancelled his approval to avoid a perception of bias in favour of the scheme.  Mr Zahawi made his comments on BBC Radio aposs Today programme - where he insisted there was no wrongdoing. He said: “The important thing by the way is the access didn’t buy this billionaire a decision. “The Secretary of State very clearly said to Richard Desmond ‘I can’t see you, I cannot have this meeting’. “So you have to also be fair and make that clear that yes of course there was access, because there was a dinner party that Robert Jenrick didn’t know he was going to sit next to Richard Desmond in. But Robert Jenrick also said in those messages that he released… ‘I can’t have this meeting with you’.  Robert Jenrick last night agreed to release correspondence relating to the Westferry Printworks development after pressure from Labour. The messages suggest Mr Jenrick made first contact with the billionaire after the dinner in November, but later told Mr Desmond he could not discuss the scheme. However, officials in the Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government made clear Mr Jenrick wanted to issue approval before the levy kicked in on January . After a frenetic exchange of e-mails within government, Mr Jenrickaposs office said he would be issuing his approval at .pm on January . The minister said yesterday: These documents show that contrary to the wild accusations and the baseless innuendo propagated by [Labour], and restated today in a series of totally inaccurate statements and comments, this was a decision taken with an open mind on the merits of the case after a thorough decision-making process.

title: top tory rushed through planning
story: NewsTop Tory rushed through planning approval to help millionaire donor avoid tax, documents suggestRobert Jenrick agreed to publish correspondence relating to the Westferry Printworks development - and they appear to show he rushed through planning approval so donor Richard Desmond could avoid a Community Infrastructure LevyShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsRobert Jenrick " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA Tory minister appears to have rushed through approval for a controversial property deal on behalf of a millionaire party donor so the development would avoid a local community tax, newly released papers suggest. Robert Jenrick tonight agreed to release correspondence relating to the Westferry Printworks development, planned by millionaire mogul Richard Desmond in East London. The redevelopment, said to be worth £ billion, was approved in January by Mr Jenrick against the recommendation of a planning inspector. The local council in Tower Hamlets were set to introduce a Community Infrastructure Levythe day after Mr Jenrick stepped in and approved the plan. The levy would have obliged Mr Desmond to contribute at least £ million to support projects in the area. The decision was reversed after legal action by Tower Hamlets Council and Mr Jenrick accepted his decision was unlawful by reason of apparent bias. In heavily redacted emails released by Mr Jenrickaposs office tonight, officials discussed the Secretary of Stateaposs sense of urgency in granting the approval. In one email discussion, an unnamed Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government official wrote: On timing, my understanding is that [Mr Jenrick] is was insistent that decision issued this week ie tomorrow - as next week the viability of the scheme is impacted by a change in the London CIL regime. Another email reads: The appellant [Mr Desmond] believes that the proposal would not be viableliable to CIL charges. Text messages between Mr Jenrick and Mr Desmond reveal conversations between the pair after they had sat at the same table at a Tory fundraiser. Arranging a site visit to view the development, Mr Desmond wrote: We appreciate the speed as we donapost want to give Marxists loads of doe for nothing. In reply, Mr Jenrick warned Mr Desmond it was important not to give any appearance of being influenced by applicants of cases that I may have a role in or to have predetermined them and so I think it is best that we donapost meet until after the matter has decided. In a later text message to which Mr Jenrick did not reply, Mr Desmond explicitly told the minister the urgency in having the development approved was to save money in taxes. Mr Desmond wrote: We have to get the approval before January  otherwise payment of  million pounds to Tower Hamlets, meaning we have to stop and reduce social housing. Thanks Robert, look forward to speaking soon, Best, Richard. According to the documents, the March site visit did not take place and no further communication followed because Mr Jenrick did not take Mr Desmondaposs  calls when he attempted to get in contact on a number of occasions. Thereaposs no record in any of the documents of Mr Jenrickaposs department taking an interest in the deal prior to the Minister and Mr Jenrick sitting at the same table at a Tory dinner in November . Mr Jenrick was the first to make written contact with Mr Desmond, sending a text after the event which read: Good to spend time with you tonight, Richard. See you again soon I hope. Mr Jenrick insisted the row over his involvement in the Westferry Printworks planning decision was politically motivated. But he agreed to release documents and correspondence relating to the decision in accordance with Freedom of Information rules. He said he would release all relevant information relating to the planning decision later today.It came after Labour warned the row had blown apart confidence in the planning system.Shadow communities secretary Steve Reed told the Commons: The only way to put that right is for the Secretary of State to publish the evidence about what really happened. If heaposs done nothing wrong then heaposs got nothing to fear. So I hope he will welcome this opportunity to restore trust in a sector that will be so critical in rebuilding Britain after the lockdown. Mr Jenrick told MPs: I will write to the chair of the select committee outlining the timeline of events and the rationale for my decision-making pertaining to the Westferry Printworks planning decision. Alongside this letter, and after a comprehensive review of what documents might be in scope of this motion, and of the letter that he sent me on behalf of his select committee, I will be releasing later today all relevant information relating to this planning matter using the Freedom of Information Act as a benchmark.

Buyers have paid up to £, for pets thought to have come from breeding farms. Many had the deadly, highly infectious canine parvovirus, along with worms and other diseases. One of the crooks, a tanned man in his s who wears a surgical mask and black gloves, is said to use aliases including Graham, Alan and Steve. Mae Goodwin, , from Tenterden in Kent, paid £, in cash for a Cavalier King Charles spaniel she called Barney – and it died of a virus eight days later. She said: “It’s just heartbreaking. They believe the crooks are operating in a gang. The RSPCA and charity Animal Protection Services have launched a probe. APS chief Jacob Lloyd said: “These are some of the worst cases I have ever seen.”

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA woman is being hailed a hero after saving a family from drowning - while topless. Jessica Layton, , from Penzance, Cornwall, was sunbathing on naturist beach near Porthcurno on Tuesday when the drama happened.She told Cornwall Live : “It was just after pm and the tide was coming in. I decided to go for a final dip before going home.I was topless in the sea when I saw two young women struggling to swim near rocks. Another member of the family ran in to help them and she started struggling too. I swam towards them and thought ‘oh s**t’ as I realised how strong the rip current was. I was struggling myself and they were panicking, which wasn’t ideal in a situation like that. The incident involved two sisters and a cousin. “I was going to tell them to float, which is the best thing you can do in a rip current, but they were panicking so much it wouldn’t have worked. They were all holding hands, so I grabbed one of their hands and pulled them all on to the beach.” Jessica – who is a performer with Cornwall’s popular Rogue Theatre – added: “One of the women said ‘aren’t you strong ’ afterwards – I’m not sure where the strength came from.” The actor and singer is a regular on the nudist beach and says people watching her rescue may have seen a lot more.  Fortunately, I’d just put my bikini bottoms on before it happened. It’s a classic – of course I was going to be topless when something like this happens! She said the family were really grateful for her heroic actions and askedshe was a leguard. Pedn Vounder doesnapost have leguard cover and is renowned among locals for being dangerous due to rip currents caused by the incoming tide.

After the UK sweltered on Wednesday, temperatures are set to rise even more, with highs of C expected in some areas. The Met Officeaposs UV index does not exceed  in the UK, but levels of  are expected across Devon and Cornwall today. A UV level of  is extremely rare, with levels  and  usually found in the Mediterranean, and  is considered aposextremeapos. UV levels could reach an all-time high in the UK as a result of clear skies and a lack of air pollution due to no flights amid the coronavirus pandemic. Met Office meteorologist Alex Burkill said that UV levels will be reaching eight across many places and will be reaching nine across parts of Devon and Cornwall today. He said: Thataposs about as high as it gets really in the UK. The sun is as strong as it gets at the moment because weaposre so close to the solstice. Weaposve got peak sun strength, clear skies, plenty of sunshine - theyaposre the perfect ingredients for high UV. If the UV level reaches , Brits could burn in just  minutesthey donapost cover up. Dr Michaela Hegglin, a professor in atmospheric chemistry at the University of Reading, said the UK could see some of the aposhighest UV levels ever recordedapos today. She told the Mail Online: This is because of a combination of factors. We are at the summer solstice, when the sun is almost directly overhead at one oaposclock. UV levels this high are rare in the UK, so people with light skin should be very careful to avoid getting burnt. While UV is important for getting vitamin D and keeping us healthy, too much of it can cause skin cancer or eye cataracts. The Met Office say precautions should be taken to stay protected. A spokesperson said: The highest levels look set to be in the south west today.  So people should avoid the sun at midday, cover up, and stay hydrated. What are UV levels  UV levels , are determined by three factors: the elevation angleof the sun in the sky, the amount of cloud, dust and pollution in the atmosphere, and the amount of ozone gas in the stratosphere. It is the bodyaposs attempts to repair these cells that causes redness and pain, also known as sunburn.   The strength of UV ies depending on where you are in the world, the time of year and on a number of dferent weather factors such as the amount of cloud cover. Small amounts of UV exposure can be beneficial as it is essential in the production of vitamin D, however over exposure of UV can lead to serious health issues. Britain continues to bask in sweltering heat, with highs of C yesterday in some parts of the country. Thursday is set to be even hotter still and record the highest temperatures of the year, but the heatwave will come to an end over the weekend, with rain and much lower temperatures forecast. Temperatures in London today will reach C, but on Saturday, the capital will see a high of just C as unsettled weather sweeps the UK. Met Office thunderstorm warnings are in place across the country from pm on Thursday until am on Saturday, which could cause flooding and disruption in some places. The weekend will see many places struggle to see temperatures in the s, with Glasgow forecast to reach just C on Sunday. Other parts of Scotland and north west England could see just C or C on Sunday, in a huge contrast to this weekaposs heatwave. And thereaposs more bad news for sunseekers as the unsettled weather looks set to dominate for the foreseeable future. The Met Office UK forecast reads: Further heavy showers for many on Saturday. Showers thereafter becoming more restricted to the northwest with most areas drier with sunny spells. Turning fresher across all areas over the weekend. A breezy and unsettled start to the period , with showers or longer spells of rain, heaviest and most frequent for some western areas. Temperatures are likely to be around average for the time of year. There will however still be some drier and sunny interludes. This changeable weather continues into July with sunshine, showers and perhaps some longer spells of rain possible for many. The rain however looks to be mainly in the northwest where it may also be cooler. The best of any drier and brighter weather will be across the south and east of the UK. Breezy conditions continuing, particularly for the north. Temperatures should mostly be around average for the time of year. It comes as a heat-health alert, level two, was issued for all of England as health officials advised the most vulnerable to protect themselves amid the exceptionally hot weather forecast this week. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThousands of Brits are appearing to defy warnings over the risk of coronavirus by packing beaches on what is expected to be the hottest day of the year. Temperatures soared to C in some parts of the UK yesterday and are set to be even hotter today as the sizzling heatwave continues. Popular beaches such as Brighton, Bournemouth and Southend were packed early on Thursday, but there appeared to be a lack of social distancing.Earlier today, Dr Hilary Jones warned Good Morning Britain viewers not to flock to packed beaches in the hot weather.He addressed the severe consequences of Covid-, especially on those above the age of , and his fear that cases could increase againpeople were to get complacent. It is feared more people will head to beaches and public areas asthe virus has gone - with Dr Hilary warning this is not the case. Telling GMB hosts Ben Shephard and Susanna Reid that people are abandoning the rules, he warned it could lead to a repeat of April when cases and even deaths from the virus soared above ,. Hilary advised those watching and those heading out to stick to the rules, in fear that the infection rate and the R number will rise as a result. He explained, after talk of the daily death rate and case rate reportedly dropping: Thataposs because lockdown has been successful. We are still seeing nearly , confirmed new cases a day after testing. If anyone could be a fly on the wall in critical care or in intensive care right now they would still see hundreds of people on ventilators and still being admitted to hospital. He went on: What we don’t want to see is the prevalence rise and the R number go up, and hospital admissions rise again.It comes as people were warned to stay hydrated while out and about in the hot conditions, with sunseekers flocking to beaches in huge numbers in recent days, despite social distancing measures still being in place.An amber level three heat-health alert, issued by the Met Office, was extended on Thursday to take in Yorkshire and the east and south of England as well as the West and East Midlands.The warning requires social and healthcare services to target specic actions at high-risk groups, according to the Met Office website. Health authorities have encouraged those most vulnerable - many of whom have been shielding during lockdown - to protect themselves amid the exceptionally hot weather forecast this week. Public Health Englandsaid older people, those with underlying health conditions, and very young children were all more at risk from the higher temperatures. It is expected temperatures in west London could reach C , while parts of Wales could see the mercury rise to C . The thermometer had already hit C at Porthmadog in Wales on Thursday morning. Temperatures reached .Cat Londonaposs Heathrow Airport at .pm on Wednesday making it the hottest day of the year so far. Met Office meteorologist John Grfiths said there was a low chance that the Welsh Marches - the area along the Welsh border - could see temperatures of Cvery locally.  Should that happen, it would be the hottest June on record in Wales, surpassing the previous peak of .Con June , . The Met Office said UV levels were expected to remain at eight across many parts of the UK on Thursday. Dr Michaela Hegglin, associate professor in atmospheric chemistry at the University of Readingaposs Department of Meteorology, said Thursday could see some of the highest UV levels ever recorded in Britain. She said: This is because of a combination of factors. We are at the summer solstice, when the sun is almost directly overhead at one oaposclock.  UV levels this high are rare in the UK, so people with light skin should be very careful to avoid getting burnt. While UV is important for getting vitamin D and keeping us healthy, too much of it can cause skin cancer or eye cataracts.Friends, family and neighbours have been urged to keep checking on the vulnerable, who might still be spending more time at home due to coronavirus, by keeping in touch on the phone.Shoppers have also been advised to be aware they could be forced to spend extra time in the sun as a result of social distancing measures, and warned to protect themselves by bringing water and wearing high factor sunscreen.Dog owners have been urged to avoid exercising their pets during the hottest part of the day, with Vets Now, a provider of emergency veterinary care, warning that the average survival rate of a dog diagnosed with heatstroke was %. Meanwhile, fire chiefs said they wanted to debunk this myth that hand sanitiser left in hot cars could pose a fire risk. Roy Wilsher, NFCC chair said: We want to reassure people that this product will not combustleft in a car - even on the hottest day. For hand sanitiser to cause a fire it would need to come into contact with a spark.

As the sun rose early this morning there were scenes of devastation on beaches such as Bournemouth and Brighton on the south coast. Tents were left on Bournemouth beach overnight along with piles of rubbish such as empty beer and cider bottles, takeaway food bags and discarded cans of Strongbow. A dog walker in Brighton wrote on Twitter: Went for an early morning walk with our dog. What is wrong with people  Loads of rubbish on the beach everywhere.  I feel for the street cleaners. Take your rubbish home or go to the next bin where it isn’t full, there’s plenty of them. It wasnapost just beaches with piles of rubbish left by revellers, similar scenes have been reported at the Meadows in Edinburgh, on Blackheath common in south east London and in Hyde Park in central London. At Hove Lawns, where pockets of violence broke out last night, rubbish was also left on the seafront, including dozens of metal cannisters used to inhale nitrous oxide - also known as aposhippy crackapos. Last night police estimated there were up to , revellers present at Hove Lawns when officers arrived after being called at .pm. Officers issued a dispersal order to clear the scene after fighting erupted among the huge group of teenagers.An eyewitness told  The Argus:  There are ten police cars and all the kids are walking around shouting at police – it’s like football chants.  All the police have pulled up and are walking along trying to get them to move. Another said: It was like a stand-off between hundreds of youths and police. Local councillor Chris Henry said: Hove Lawns tonight shows how badly solutions for young people are needed and how youth services are needed more than ever.The weather is set to be even hotter today with beaches expected to be packed again - with locals fearing similar scenes throughout the summer with people wary of going to pubs and preferring to drink in the sunshine.  Natalie Joyce wrote on Twitter : I am genuinely confused by the state of some of Dorsetaposs beaches today.I cannot get my head around why people would leave their rubbish and think that it is ok ! No one actually knowsit is locals or people who have travelled to the area, either way - it is bang out of order! Writing about the pictures from Bournemouth Angie said: And the downside of living in Bournemouth. Selfish, entitled humans. aposI want to go to the beach, I don’t careothers do too, I want to eat, get tanned and then leave my rubbish for someone apos. At famous beauty spot Durdle Door  bags of rubbish were reported to have been collected by volunteers. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPrince Harry and Meghan Markle are set to make millions on the professional speaking circuit after reportedly signing with a high-profile agency who represent Barack and Michelle Obama, as well as Bill and Hillary Clinton. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex, who quit their royal le in Britain to set up home in Los Angeles, have struck a deal with the New York-based Harry Walker Agency. Former President Barack Obama reportedly earned almost £, for one  speech, while the Clintons averaged almost £, per appearance in . It is unclear what speaking fees will be for the Duke and Duchess, who will speak both together or inidually, the Los Angeles Times reported. A source close to Harry and Meghan reportedly confirmed the couple had signed with the agency, which industry insiders say will net them millions as they seek “financial independence” away from the royal family. It is expected they will offer their services as keynote speakers with big money corporations and community forums in future. Harry in February spoke at an event hosted by investment banking giant JP Morgan where he revealed he had been in therapy for the past three years.
