title: racing-gets-green-light-return
story: Musselburgh Racecourse will stage the first of five meeting on the last day of the month with fixtures also planned for Wednesday, July .They will be followed by fixtures scheduled on Friday, July , Thursday, July , and Wednesday, August .The first race in Scotland since the Covid outbreaktakes place at Ayr this Monday .It is expected other fixtures will be assigned by the British Horseracing Authority in due course to Musselburgh and Scotlandrsquos other four racecourses.Musselburghrsquos management team hasestablished procedures for hosting controlled meetings without spectators which meet the highest health and safety and bio-security standards and have been working closely with East Lothian Council and Police Scotland in preparation for the resumption of racing.Bill Farnsworth, Musselburgh Racecourse general manager, welcomed the announcement and said Scottish racing was fully prepared to play a vital role in supporting owners, trainers and the wider horseracing sector.He said: ldquoControlled horseracing meetings have been very successfully introduced in England, Ireland and a number of other countries and we are looking forward to playing our part in getting the wheels of the industry turning again in Scotland.Racing fans will be able to follow the action through a number of dferent options, including live screening on Racing TV, ITV Racing, on catch up via Racing TV Player, and through bookmakers websites for those who have accounts.Joe FitzPatrickMSP, minister for public health,sport  wellbeing, said: ldquoIrsquom sure that this news will be welcomed by racing fans across the country. The resumption of professional sports is another step towards some level of normality and its safe resumption is only possible thanks to a constructive relationship between the Scottish Government and bodies like Scottish Racing.Delly Innes, manager of Scottish Racing, said: ldquoWe are delighted to welcome theof racing in Scotland after a long, but necessary, absence as Scotland faced the challenges of Covid-. This has been an immensely challenging time for our five excellent racecourses, but this is an important first step on the road to recovery, and we will be working hard to ensure all our participants are familiar with, and adhere to Scottish rules and guidance where these dfer from UK guidance.ldquoWe are raring to go with an exciting programme of fixtures in the months ahead which will help support the wider Scottish and British racing industry, and provide entertainment to viewers across the country.

title: community-resilience-volunteers-humbie-east-west-saltoun-bolton-musselburgh-ormiston
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at four of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Humbie, East and West Saltoun, and BoltonRESIDENTS across East and West Saltoun, Humbie and Bolton continue to help and look after each other and plans are being made for how the effort will continue, once volunteers start going back to work.Derek Smith, the single point of contactin West Saltoun, said that people in the area were ldquocarrying on doing as we do and continued to look after each other.For example, two households will do the shopping for another four, and residents from another village have been delivering logs to those who need them.Derek said: ldquoWersquove been helping each other out.ldquoThe number of people in the village who need shopping, or those sheltering and so on, will continue [getting support] as long as itrsquos needed.ldquoIn a village this size, we all know each other, andanyone needs something they can knock on someonersquos door. There is always someone they can get in touch with.Considering how the effort will continue now restrictions are starting to ease, Derek said: ldquoThings may well change as people go back to work. There may be a drop of capability and volunteers able to continue on some basis.He added that the local resilience plan has been updated to include a pandemic, should one happen again in the future. Plans were previously prepared for bad weather, such as the snow seen in the lsquoBeast from the Eastrsquo.In Humbie, the first weekly soup-and-sandwich lunch was delivered last Wednesdayto local residents who are isolating or severely restricting their movements.The aim of the lunch is to provide some socially distanced contact and something for residents to look forward to each week.Al Beck, from Humbie, East  West Saltoun and Bolton Community Council, said: ldquoEverything looked great and the lunch, together with the brief visit by our volunteers, was warmly received by everyone.The project is planned to run for the next approximately eight weeks.One resident said: ldquoThank you all for the lsquosouperrsquo lunch, we really enjoyed it. Had a lovely wee chat with the lady who delivered.Another said: ldquoThank you all, my mum enjoyed her lunch and apparently was going to share her scone, but decided to eat it all herself as she said it was too good to share.Those who live in the Humbie and Fala area and are interested in the soupand-sandwich lunch, either for themselves or for someone  they know, are encouraged to get in touch with Margo Hodge.For those needing assistance, people in Bolton should contact Shena Jamieson on   or by email at shenajamieson@aolEast Saltoun residents can contact Buffy Neilson on   or buffyneilson@yahooIn West Saltoun, Derek Smith is the point of contact on   or by emailing coruisk@gmailIn Humbie, residents are encouraged to call Margo Hodge on   or email humbiehelp@gmailMusselburghGARDENING tools are on loan through Resilient Musselburgh during the Covid- crisis.They have been provided by the Musselburgh Tool Library and everything from strimmers, lawn mowers, edgers, hedge trimmers, hoes, rakes, spades and forks can be borrowed.Tools can be booked by calling the Musselburgh community response phone line on  .They will be delivered direct to householders on a Friday morning between .am and .am and collected at the same time the following week.Jane Cummings, from East Lothian Councilrsquos Connected Communities, said: ldquoThis is a temporary service to help people maintain and enjoy their gardens during the summer months. There is no charge but tools must be booked in advance.Resilient Musselburgh also submitted a short video competition entry to Nisarsquos charity lsquoMaking a Dference Locallyrsquo on how it spent the companyrsquos pound donation, which was received in May.This video has won an award of an additional pound, towards the community response in Musselburgh, Whitecraig, Wallyford and Old Craighall.Resilient Musselburgh is being led by Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council and Musselburgh Area Partnership, helped by an army of around  volunteers.It is continuing to deliver food and prescriptions to vulnerable people in the area during the coronavirus crisis.OrmistonTHE Pennypit Community Development Trust has put out an appeal for supplies of groceries, toiletries, and other items to help them continue supplying surrounding communities during the ongoing lockdown.Ormiston Community Council said it received a fantastic response after sharing the appeal on Ormi Folks Facebook page, with several volunteers collecting donations and delivering them to St Martinrsquos Hall to be distributed.Councillors thanked everyone who contributed to the appeal.The community resilience team is currently assessing the way forward, with some volunteers now ing to work and the likelihood that some of those who needed help during the first phase of lockdown may not need as much support as the easing of restrictions continues.Scott Gillies, community council chairman, said: ldquoWe are now assessing how things will continue now that some volunteers are ing to work, and also some who were needing help during the initial lockdown period may not need as much assistance.ldquoWe feel we still have adequate cover to continue the food deliveries, carry out shopping and pick up prescriptions for the time being.If anyone in Ormiston requires help they can contact the team on   between am and pm, seven days a week, or email Ormistonrcrteam@hotmail

title: lifeboat-called-assist-kayaker-distress
story: The crew was paged at .am by the Coastguard after the kayaker had fallen into the water while fishing half a mile off shore.The all weather leboat was launched from nearby Torness Power Station at .am.Two crew members were on board and set off to try and locate the man.They received help from a passing angler who had spotted him clinging to his boat, they then rescued the man and helped him aboard the leboat.The crew ed to the shore and helped the man reach coastguard teams from Dunbar and North Berwick.The man was said to be extremely cold and shivery and was then assessed by paramedics, he appeared to otherwise be uninjured.The leboat crew then helped recover the manrsquos kayak and at am were stood down by the Coastguard.A Dunbar RNLI spokesman said: ldquoAlthough the kayaker was well-equipped he had been in the water for sometime and was initially reluctant to call for help. We would urge anyone in dficulty in or near the water to call  and ask for the Coastguard.As Scotland moves into phase two of easing lockdown restrictions, Dunbar RNLI urged that boat users be prepared before ing to the water.As boats have been sitting idle for the past few months people are asked to make sure they have good, fresh fuel in the tank and that water and oil are at the correct levels.People are asked to check weather forecasts and sea conditions before setting off and to always wear a lejacket, should a person fall into the water unexpectedly they are four times more likely to survivewearing one.They are also asked to carry a means to call for help and to not put themselves, their family or the emergency services at risk.

title: far-can-travel-scotlands-phase-2-can-drive-england
story: Early on in her briefing, Nicola Sturgeon said that as part of the ldquostaged approach, the Scottish Government guidance will continue to be asking people to ldquoas far as possible to stay within or close to their local area.She added that their ambition ldquois to be in a position to lt this in Phase  and in time for the proposed resumption of tourism from July .How far can I travel At this stage for leisure and recreation purposes, Ms Sturgeon says people should ldquonot travel more than five miles or so from their home.She added: ldquoOutdoor businesses, such as zoos and garden attractions, can also reopen from June  ndash although people should not be travelling more than five miles to visit them and tickets should be bought in advance.The retail sector is also set to open on June .However she added that, as revealed previously, the five-mile limitdoes NOT apply to meeting family and friends.These meetings should take place outdoors, but under new Phase  measures you can go inside to use the toilet.Can I travel to England A Scottish Government spokesperson says that as long as you can get there and back in one day, you can visit family in England.They told the Scotsman that it would be fine to travel to, for example, Carlisle or Berwick, to visit family ndash so long as you do not have to stay overnight.The spokesman did however advise against travelling too far, adding it would become more dficult to make it back in one day ndash urging people to ldquoexercise common sense in their actions.Can I use public transport Public transport is continuing to operate at a massively reduced capacity to allow for physical distancing.But under Phase , there will be a slight increase in services ndash but with new rules.From today, face coverings are mandatory on all public transport in Scotland, with customers urged to avoid peak times wherever possible to allow for key workers to use the services.

story: The eastbound carriageway between the Gladsmuir junction and Oaktree junction, near Haddington, will be closed from pm tomorrow until am on Thursdaywhile work is carried out.A ersion will be put in place and signposted, taking people via the B, A through Gladsmuirand then onto the B into Haddington.The following night , the westbound carriageway will be closed from Gladsmuir to the Bankton junction, north of Tranent,from pm on Thursday night until am on Friday morning .A ersion will take people on the A, which passes through Tranent.The works, which are described by operating company Amey as ldquoessential, are estimated to cost about pound,.Amey said the work will ldquoimprove safety and reduce overall maintenance costs by mitigating the need for further reactive repairs.Work is being completed by a contractor on behalf of Amey and Transport Scotland.While the work is being carried out, physical distancing will be in place to ensure all staff on site remain safe.Thorough risk assessments will be carried out and cleansing stations will also be put in place on site.For more information visit scottishtrunkroadsse-live.amey a overnight-roadworks-on-the-a--juneor East Lothian Councils website and Facebook page.

title: 1-650-spent-remind-residents-keep-distance
story: The ft-high information boards have been produced to remind people to follow social distancing rules as restrictions on outdoor gatherings are eased.With the message Keep East Lothian Moving, the boards remind people to maintain a two-metre distance and "consider others when youre out and about".The messages are accompanied by images of people out walking their dogs, with their families, running and cycling and an elderly person using a walking aid, as well as a skateboarder.East Lothian Council said it had invested more than pound, in the boards which will appear across  key sites.The move comes as the local authority also deployed mobile electronic signs on the A coast road over the weekend reminding people to stay local.The electronic signs, usually used to deter speeding on the road, changed its message as the council reopened its larger coastal car parks for local residents to use.They warned people not to stray too far from their home comforts with the message, Stay Local No Public Toilets.A council spokesperson said the new social distance boards would be placed at sites around the county.They said: ldquoAt this stage, we have identied  locations in dferent parts of East Lothian where these materials, highlighting the importance of physical distancing guidelines, will be put in place."Thirty copies have been ordered at a cost of pound,.

title: losing-sense-smell-coronavirus---happens
story: FROM the first reports coming out of Wuhan, Iran and later Italy, we knew that losing your sense of smellwas a signicant symptom of the disease.Now, after months of reports, both anecdotal and more rigorous clinical findings, we think we have a model for how this virus may cause smell loss.One of the most common causes of smell loss is a viral infection, such as the common cold, sinus or other upper respiratory tract infections.Those coronaviruses that donrsquot cause deadly diseases, such as COVID-, Sars and Mers, are one of the causes of the common cold and have been known to cause smell loss.In most of these cases, sense of smell s when symptoms clear, as smell loss is simply the result of a blocked nose, which prevents aroma molecules reaching olfactory receptors in the nose. In some cases, smell loss can persist for months and years.For the novel coronavirus , however, the pattern of smell loss is dferent. Many people with COVID- reported a sudden loss of sense of smell and then a sudden and fullto a normal sense of smell in a week or two.Interestingly, many of these people said their nose was clear, so smell loss cannot be attributed to a blocked nose.For others, smell loss was prolonged and several weeks later they still had no sense of smell. Any theory of anosmia in COVID- has to account for both of these patterns.This suddenof a normal sense of smell suggests an obstructive smell loss in which the aroma molecules cannot reach the receptors in the nose .Now that we have CT scans of the noses and sinuses of people with COVID- smell loss, we can see that the part of the nose that does the smelling, the olfactory cleft, is blocked with swollen soft tissue and mucus ndash known as a cleft syndrome.The rest of the nose and sinuses look normal and patients have no problem breathing through their nose.We know that the way SARS-CoV- infects the body is by attaching to ACE receptors on the surface of cells that line the upper respiratory tract.A protein called TMPRSS then helps the virus invade the cell. Once inside the cell, the virus can replicate, triggering the immune systemrsquos inflammatory response. This is the starting point for the havoc and destruction that this virus causes once in the body.Initially, we thought that the virus might be infecting and destroying the olfactory neurons.These are the cells that transmit the signal from the aroma molecule in your nose to the area in the brain where these signals get interpreted as ldquosmell.However, an international collaboration showed recently that the ACE proteins the virus needs to invade the cells were not found on the olfactory neurons.But they were found on cells called ldquosustentacular cells, which support the olfactory neurons.We expect that these support cells are likely to be the ones that are damaged by the virus, and the immune response would cause swelling of the area but leave the olfactory neurons intact.When the immune system has dealt with the virus, the swelling subsides and the aroma molecules have a clear route to their undamaged receptors and the sense of smell s to normal.So why does smell notin some cases This is more theoretical but follows from what we know about inflammation in other systems.Inflammation is the bodyrsquos response to damage and results in the release of chemicals that destroy the tissues involved.When this inflammation is severe, other nearby cells start to be damaged or destroyed by this ldquosplash damage. We believe that accounts for the second stage, where the olfactory neurons are damaged.Recovery of smell is much slower because the olfactory neurons need time to regenerate from the supply of stem cells within the lining of the nose.Initial recovery is often associated with distortion of the sense of smell known as parosmia, where things donrsquot smell like they used to.For many parosmics, for instance, the smell of coffee is often described as burnt, chemical, dirty and reminiscent of sewage.Physiotherapy for the noseOlfaction has been called the Cinderella of the senses because of its neglect by scientic research.But it has come to the forefront in this pandemic. The silver lining is that we will learn a lot about how viruses are involved in smell loss from this. But what hope is there for people with a loss of smell now The good news is that the olfactory neurons can regenerate. Theyrsquore regrowing in almost all of us, all of the time. We can harness that regeneration and guide it with ldquophysiotherapy for the nose: smell training.

title: headteacher-praised-leadership-style
story: North Berwick High Schools head Lauren Rodgerwas described by Education Scotland inspectors as having a clear direction and being well respected.However while the inspection, carried out in February,praised the staff and leadership at the school and achievements of its senior students, it pointed to improvements required to enable more S-S pupils to learn a foreign language.The report called for more work to be done to ensure all younger students received their full entitlement to Broad General Educationin the first three years at the school.In particular it stated: "Currently, a few young people are not experiencing a modern language until the end of S."Inaddition, the current arrangement is not sufficient for young people to receive their entitlementto a meaningful experience of a third language."Inspectors urged the school to ensure the focus was on ensuring younger pupils received full access to experiences across the curriculum and did not allow a focus on reaching exam levels to impact on them.The inspectors said: "Teachers should ensure that learning at Sacross all curriculum areas remains focused on the experiences and outcomes of CfEanddoes not prioritise the requirements of National Qualications ."Senior and middle leadersshould ensure that learning experiences in S provide those young people specialising atfourth level with appropriate depth in their learning to provide successful progression to thesenior phase."Inspectors visited the school in February  and assessed the schoolrsquos performance across four key indicators: leadership of change learning, teaching and assessment raising attainment and achievement and ensuring wellbeing, equality and inclusion.The school was evaluated as lsquovery goodrsquo in the first three categories and lsquogoodrsquo in the fourth.Headteacher Lauren Rodgerrsquos leadership style was described as ldquocharacterised by openness and by trust, promoting empowerment in a supportive ethos. Inspectors highlighted the strong leadership at all staff levels and the use of effective research to support creative learning.Innovative approaches to teaching and assessment encourage young people to take responsibility for their own learning. Where young people are facing personal challenges, the report noted that targeted strategies are used to support them, and an open climate exists within the school around mental health.As part of the process, inspectors make recommendations for areas of improvement. The letter outlines recommendations that the school continues with its improvements to the planning process for S-S and reviews its approaches for checking on pupilrsquos wellbeing.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, East Lothian Councils cabinet spokesperson for education and childrenrsquos services, said: ldquoIrsquod like to congratulate Lauren Rodger and her team on a very positive report. The inspectorsrsquo comments regarding strong leadership and how this supports pupilsrsquo attainment through creative learning and personal responsibility is a real testament to the school teamrsquos positive work and ethos."Thisreport will provide confidence and comfort for parents and carers, and is much-welcomed good news for the school community.Lesley Brown, chief operating officer for education at the local authority, said: ldquoIrsquom sure this report will be welcomed by everyone connected with North Berwick High School."Irsquom especially pleased to see inspectors recognise the work that staff and pupils have undertaken to open-up conversations around mental health and wellbeing."This will be especially important in the months ahead as weto school, and is very much in line with our approach to use nurture to help reconnect and recover from Covid. Irsquod like to commend Lauren Rodger and her team on their achievements and their commitment to creating such strong learning opportunities.

title: staycation-five-scotlands-photogenic-places-visit-lockdown-eases
story: After exactly three months of lockdown things are starting to look up ndash and just last week it was revealed Scotlandrsquos tourism sector ndash including hotels, pubs and restaurants ndash could reopen from July .And with our beautul scenery, immersing history and friendly locals, therersquos no wonder why some research shows more than half of Brits are eyeing up a lsquostaycationrsquo this year rather than opting to go abroad.With that in mind, wersquove detailed outfiveof the most photogenic lsquostaycationrsquo locations to visit in Scotland once lockdown measures are eased.Harris, Outer HebridesWhen thinking about a lsquostaycationrsquo in Scotland, itrsquos understandable that a beach holiday isnrsquot the first thing on your mind.But the Outer Hebrides beaches are some of the most beautul in Europe ndash and it would be hard to blame youyou thought it was somewhere in the Caribbeanhellip perhaps only the temperature would give it away.In March, Luskentyre Bay on Harris was named as one of the top  beaches in the world by Tripadvisor.The far-flung, sandy outpost - which is reached by a single track road - was rated higher than sun-soaked destinations in Spain, the Caribbean, and the golden shores of Florida to take th spot in the prestigious s Travellers Choice Awards.Described by the sites visitors "as close to heaven as you could get", the expanse of Luskentyre Bay sits on the South of Harris, close to the isolated island of Taransay, where the seminal BBC reality series Castaway  was filmed.Tobermory, MullIt doesnrsquot take a tourism expert to identy the colourful harbour-front buildings of Tobermory from the popular childrenrsquos TV show Balamory.The capital of Mull, Tobermory is arguably one of the prettiest ports in Scotland thanks to the before-mentioned colourful houses and sheltered bay.Legend has it that Tobermory was the location of the sinking of Spanish Armada ship in , carrying gold bullion.You can find out all about the history of the area in the Mull museum ndash orgolf is more of your fancy then therersquos a nine-hole course sitting in the clfs above the bay.The ldquotough challenge offers panoramic views across to the Ardnamurchan Peninsula and, on a clear day, the Isle of Skye.The bay is also a departure point for whale watching and wildle cruises.Eilean Donan, HighlandsItrsquos the most photographed castle in Scotland and has been featured in blockbuster films including James Bond.Recognised around the world as one of the most iconic images of Scotland, itrsquos little wonder the castle is now one of the most visited attractions in the Scottish Highlands.Strategically located on its own little island overlooking the isle of Skye, the castle sits where three lochs ndash Loch Duich, Loch Long and Loch Alsh meet.Surrounded by the mountains of Kintail, visitors have the chance to wander around the internal rooms of the castle while also taking in the wonderful wildle that surrounds the island too ndash with porpoise, dolphins, otters and birdle sightings an often occurrence.Arran, North AyrshireThe Isle of Arran is often described as ldquoScotland in Miniature, soyoursquore looking for a quick staycation but with a lot to experience then look no further.The ever-changing coastline, dramatic mountain peaks, sheltered beaches and tasty local produce makes a holiday in Arran unforgettable.Donrsquot forget to pack your camera ndash with the stunning views of and from the islandrsquos largest mountain, Goatfell, worth capturing.Not only that but the island boasts a wealth of nature, including red squirrels, deer, golden eagles, otters, seals and basking sharks just waiting to be snapped up.Glenfinnan Viaduct, HighlandsMade ever more popular by the Harry Potter films, the Glenfinnan Viaduct attracts thousands of visitors from across the world every year.The special atmosphere and the stunning scenery overlooking the famous railway track makes for some magical images ndash no wonder why they chose it for the wizarding films.The famous viaduct carries the railway to Glenfinnan station across a ft span, ft above the ground ndash and the Jacobite steam train runs from here to Fort William and Mallaig in the summer months.Visitors are reminded, however, that trespassing on the railway line is extremely dangerous and they should stay clear of the tracks at all times.Full details of all the locations and more are available on Visit Scotlands website here.And remember: Do not travel for leisure until the Scottish Government guidance says it is acceptable to do so.

title: bbc-tv-licence-payments-75s-delayed-october
story: It comes after anational newspaper reported earlier thisweek on theintroduction of mandatory TV licences for over s - suggesting they would be making them pay the annual charge ofpound.from this October, rather thanAugust.However, the BBC have quickly moved to clary the situation.What have the BBC said In relation to an article published in the , aBBC spokesperson said: ldquoThe BBC has made no such decision and it is wrong to suggest we have."The BBCs position is that we have delayed implementation until August - and we are doing what we have always said - which is keeping that decision under review."The BBC will announce its decision in July."Why were the plans delayed Initially, over-s would have had to begin paying in June, but plans were pushed back to August in the wake of the coronavirus crisis.TV licenses were deemed necessary in keeping over-s - who are more at risk from the effects of Covid- - informed as the pandemic spread.Chairman of the BBC, Sir David Clementi, said at the time: "The BBC board has decided to delay changes to over s licence fees."We are in exceptional circumstances. Now is not the right time. We are fully focused on delivering our services to the public at this dficult time."Reaction to the moveLord Foulkes, the chairman of the All-Party Group for Ageing and Older People, said: "The Government should cover the cost as a social benefit and not burden the BBC, which is already strapped for cash."We will continue to work on this vital campaign alongside the likes of Age UK, as well as a growing number of MPs and peers."Caroline Abrahams, the charity director at Age UK, added: "While many older people are being advised to stay mostly at home, or are too worried to go out, free TV licences for over-s should continue."The last thing they need is to have to get to grips with a new TV licence scheme, or risk prosecutionthey get it wrong."When were free TV licences for over s introduced Free TV licences for over s were introduced by Labour PM Gordon Brown, and were first paid for by a Labour government in .

title: can-move-home-scotland-rules-need-know-measures-eased
story: During her announcement of Phase  on June , the First Minister revealed that restrictions on the housing market will be relaxed from June  ndash this coming Monday.That announcement, according to ESPC, sparked a rise in demand for property in Scotland ndash with viewing requests, home report and schedule downloads at the highest level theyrsquove been since pre-lockdown.Here, wersquove collated some of the key guidance from the Scottish Government ahead of the changes on Monday ndash in a bid to make moving home as smooth as possible during the lockdown.What do I need to know From June , all home moves are permitted, provided they can be carried out safely.This includes students moving home and other home moves resulting in two households merging.It also applies to custom and self-builders looking to acquire a plot or a property to renovate or to demolish.Under what circumstances can I leave my home While in normal circumstances, under current guidance you are only allowed to travel more than five miles to visit family or friends.But these rules do not come in to force when done in connection with the purchase, sale, letting or rental of a residential property.The activities allowed under those rules are:Also, under the guidance published on Tuesday, people working for relevant organisations and businesses in the housing sector can also travel to work where necessary to undertake these activities in a safe manner.What changes will remain The Scottish Government has said that the process will ldquonot be ato normality, and instead said it ldquowill have to adapt practices and procedures to ensure the risk of the spread of COVID- is reduced as far as possible.This includes more of the process going online ndash for example virtual viewing and valuations where possible.The following measures should be followed:What  should I know The Scottish Government advice says that surveyors should not enter a property where a member of the household is showing symptoms of COVID- or self-isolating.When moving your belongings, it is worth remembering that removal firms are able to operate ndash however you may wish to make your own arrangements to move belongings.The guidance also encourages everyone to be as flexible as possible during this period and be prepared to delay moves ndash for examplesomeone has to self-isolate or falls ill during the moving process.Full details can be found on the Scottish Government website here.#

title: laughing-gas-canisters-found-discarded-longniddry-bents
story: Users ndash who usually inhale the gas using a balloon ndash get a temporary high but can become panicky and confused.During a clear up of Longniddry Bents last week,  discarded canisters were found, alongside hundreds of empty alcohol bottles.Chief Inspector Neil Mitchell,the local area police commander, has warned of a trend among young people of nitrous oxide use and urged parents to speak to their children about its dangers.The father-of-two said it was ldquoextremely concerning and told the Courier: ldquoInhaling the gas slows downmessages between the brain and body, causing temporary feelings of calmness and joy.ldquoNegative effects can include dizziness, headaches or fainting. It can also cause confusion and cloud judgement. Sometimes the user can see or hear things that arenrsquot real.ldquoThe risks include it preventing the ability to breathe and, in extreme cases, death.ldquoIt can cause the heart rate to beat irregularly, increasing the risk of heart failure and heavy use has been linked to vitamin B deficiency which can cause nerve damage.ldquoAs well as these, the user can become confused and panicky which may lead to accidents.The gas is not illegal and can be bought widely online and is used by dentists and medical professionals to sedate patients for minor medical procedures.The officer stressed it was ldquonot something we want our children and young people experimenting with.A spokesperson for Midlothian and East Lothian Drugs and Alcohol Partnershipsaid: ldquoWe would like to remind the public that laughing gas might sound fun, but the risks are not.ldquoNitrous oxide slows down messages between the brain and body.ldquoNegative effects can include dizziness, headaches or fainting and dficulty in your ability to breathe.ldquoIt can also cause confusion and clouded judgement.ldquoThis may put you at higher risk of accidents.ldquoIt is best to avoid using nitrous oxide, especiallyyou have an underlying health condition and mixing it with other drugs, particularly alcohol, increases the risk of harm.ldquoAnyone seeking further assistance, support or advice is advised to contact MYPAS who provide a friendly, confidential and nonjudgemental drug and alcohol support for young people in East Lothian and Midlothian.Sharon Saunders, head of communities and partnerships at East Lothian Council, said: ldquoWe have had reports of the misuse of these canisters from a number of council services including Safer Communities, Countryside Rangers and MELDAP and, as leaders of services for children and young people, we are all concerned that people know of this developing trend and the signicant risks associated with use of these canisters.ldquoUsing these canisters poses signicant health concerns as itrsquos a harmful and potentially lethal substance and itrsquos important that young people and their families are aware of the real and signicant health risks associated with using these canisters.Kenny MacAskill, East Lothianrsquos MP, and Iain Gray, the countyrsquos MSP, backed plans for a multi-agency meeting to tackle the issue.Mr MacAskill said: ldquoOne of the main problems in this case is one of supply.ldquoThe substance can feel quite easy to get hold of, but this is absolutely no indicator that it is safe.ldquoIt is extremely dangerous, especially for those with undiagnosed or asymptomatic illnesses.ldquoYoung people who are abusing it are taking huge risks themselves and for their friends as well.ldquoOne of the problems is that there are legitimate uses for the capsules, especially in the catering industry.ldquoThere needs to be a well-rounded approach to tackling this latest trend, involving education, support from the police and responsible vendors.Mr Gray was similarly keen to see the issue tackled and encouraged anyone with information to contact the police.He said: ldquoThere have been widespread reports of large numbers of these discarded canisters being found in areas across the UK over recent weeks.ldquoThe fact that so many were found in one place here suggests that this is also a problem locally and one that will undoubtedly be of concern to parents.ldquoIrsquom pleased to see that a multiagency response is being pursued to help tackle the issue, and would certainly echo what has been said about parents discussing the potential risks with their children and reporting any relevant information to the police.Ch Insp Mitchell urged parents, writing in his Courier column: ldquoPlease do all you can to talk to your children, discuss the dangers of these canisters and of the impact of anti-social behaviour.ldquoEventhey havenrsquot been part of the group, they may know who has been and please report any concerns to us on the  number or  in an emergency.ldquoIf we all work together we can improve our communities and keep our children and young people safe.

title: chester-takes-reins-musselburgh-racecourse
story: East Lothian Council has confirmed that a contract handing operations of the course to Chester, who will operate the course as Musselburgh Racecourse Ltd,was signed earlier today.The racecourse ndash which is on Common Good land ndash was put out to tender for third party operators in  after a troubled history surrounding its management committee saw the British Horseracing Authority demand an independent review of its governacne.A new Musselburgh Racing Associated Committee was established with four elected councillors and two representatives of Lothians Racing Syndicate, to oversee the transfer to new operators.Chester wasnamed as the preferred bidder in October last year but negotiations were delayed by the coronavirus crisis.The handover comes just days before Musselburgh welcomes theof racing with its first fixtures being held behind closed doors on Tuesday, June  and Wednesday, July .Councillor Fiona OrsquoDonnell, MRAC chairperson, said: ldquoI welcome the completion of the transfer of Musselburgh racecourse to the new operator, Musselburgh Racecourse Limited, part of Chester Racecoursersquos group of companies."I want to thank all the members of the Musselburgh Racing Association, and its predecessor, MJRC, for their contributions over the years, both councillors and representatives of the LRS."It is their work and the staff team which has transformed the racecourse into a five star visitor attraction."I look forward to a positive working relationship with the new operators as we move forward into this new chapter in the history of the racecourse, to the benefit of everyone involved, the community of Musselburgh and the wider East Lothian economy

title: aldi-asda-tesco-sainsburys-m-s-update-face-mask-rules
story: It comes after the UK government released guidance in May regarding the wearing of masks in both essential and non-essential shops.Currently, it remainsoptional as to whether they should be worn inside shops and supermarkets. But the major chains have put their own guidance in place.What is the latest government guidance The government guidance says: "If you can, wear a face covering in an enclosed space where social distancing isnrsquot possible and where you will come into contact with people you do not normally meet.ldquoThis is most relevant for short periods indoors in crowded areas, for example on public transport or in some shops.Many shoppers have since taken the decision to wear masks in stores.Weve put together a round-up of what the rules are on face masks from all of the major supermarkets.AldiAt present, customershave the choice they want to wear a face covering or not in store.In a statement, the supermarket added:"Aldi will be providing the option of face masks to all its store-based colleagues to further support their safety as they continue to feed the nation."This move is in addition to the previously announced provision of gloves and clear screens that are being installed at more than , checkouts."Colleagues can also now access the Governmentrsquos Covid- testing programme for critical workers.AsdaShoppers also have the choicethey want to wear a face mask when at Asda.A spokesman from Asda said: "We are complying with all Government guidelines and we welcome customers wearing face masks or not."Our colleagues all have the option of wearing face masks which we have supplied and the colleagues in clinical settingshave been required to wear masks since the start of the pandemic as per the government guidelines on clinical workers."TescoLike other retailers, Tesco has not has not made wearing masks compulsory for any of their shoppers or any of their staff.Social distancing rules remain in place, with a restriction onthe number of travel to their place of work.MSIt has been reported that face visors have been available to staff since the beginning of April. But, thewearing of the visors - or any face coverings - has not been enforced in store.Again, like other supermarkets, it is up to customersthey want to weara face mask or not.

title: queen-margaret-universitys-catering-team-delivers-tasty-results
story: BaxterStorey, the universityrsquos catering services partner, has been helping charities and community groups.Julie Smith, general manager, and her team have been operating a pop-up shop and takeaway from Maggiersquos Bar and Cafe in the Studentsrsquo Union throughout lockdown, keeping students and local residents stocked up with essential household items.They also joined forces with the Studentsrsquo Union, student support service ResLe, and the University and College Union branch to put together  wellbeing packs for students living in university accommodation.And BaxterStorey and the university have been supporting Empty Kitchens, Full Hearts, a social enterprise which produces packs of hot meals, fruit and vegetables for vulnerable groups.Davie Beattie, one of the BaxterStorey chefs, has been helping to cover shts in the kitchen at the Carberry Residential Home near Musselburgh.A university spokesperson said: ldquoDaviersquos support has been invaluable at this time due to some of the homersquos kitchen staff being in the shielding group or having to self-isolate.Julie said: ldquoI feel incredibly privileged to have such a committed and passionate team and to have been afforded the opportunity to support the local community.Sarah Whigham, acting head of commercial services at QMU, said: ldquoIrsquom so proud of everything that Julie and the BaxterStorey team have done to help the local community in these challenging times.

title: poignant-picture-tribute-paid-mark-mens-day
story: Co-op Funeralcare invited families to send in photos of their fathers or other male loved ones they wanted to remember and pay tribute to.The images were used in a montage that filled the windows of its High Street shop on Sunday, which it renamed Menrsquos Day.The memorial window was created by the Co-op team, who hoped it would offer comfort to those who have lost someone and wanted to remember them, at what staff members said could be a dficult time of the year.Lee Stewart, funeral director at the Tranent branch, said: ldquoWe recognise that, even though your dad, or any male figure, may not be here any more, you still think of him every day.ldquoFatherrsquos Day is a wonderful celebration but it can be a particularly dficult and poignant time for bereaved families, especially considering the current climate.ldquoWe thought the window would be a lovely way to symbolise how united Tranent is during the pandemic, as well as honouring every dad and male figure who has sadly passed away, hence why we decided to call it lsquoMenrsquos Dayrsquo instead of Fatherrsquos Day.ldquoWe have been inundated with pictures from families, which has been incredibly heart-warming to see.It is not the first time the team in Tranent has used the shop windows to mark special occasions and pay tribute.In November last year, a display in honour of the countyrsquos war heroes and recognising their sacrices was created, with medals, ration books, memorabilia and other tributes on show.Lee said: ldquoWe take pride in our funeral home being at the very heart of the local community.ldquoEvery day, our staff work extremely hard to assist families during these very dficult times, and wersquore always on hand to comfort and support families throughout the bereavement process.

title: coronavirus-vaccine-uk-trials-begin-humans---long-take
story: The clinical team in the capital are currently developing and trialling the Imperial Covid- vaccine, thanks to more than pound million in funding from the UK government, and a further pound million in philanthropic donations.First dose lsquodelivered safelyrsquoA small dose of the vaccine was administered to the volunteer - who requested to remain anonymous - at a West London facility on Tuesday .The participant is now being closely monitored by the clinical team, who have since reported they are in good health, with no safety concerns.The dose is to be followed with a second booster dose within a four week period.The possible coronavirus vaccine has undergone rigorous pre-clinical safety tests, and has been shown to be safe during animal studies. It has also produced encouraging signs of an effective immune response.Potential to revolutionise vaccine developmentThe current trial marks the first test of a new self-amplying RNAtechnology, which has the potential to revolutionise vaccine development and enable scientists to respond more quickly to emerging diseases.Dr Katrina Pollock, from Imperialrsquos Department of Infectious Disease and Chief Investigator of the study, said that the delivery of the first dose signals a signicant milestone in the study, after being administered safely.Leader of the work, Professor Robin Shattock, added, "The first participant marks an important step for our saRNA vaccine , which has never before been trialled in humans."We now eagerly await rapid recruitment to the trial so that we can assess both the safety of the vaccine and its ability to produce neutralising antibodies which would indicate an effective response against COVID-. I look forward to our progress in the coming months."What will happen next Several other volunteers are expected to be given their first dose of the vaccine over the next few days, and will be monitored closely by the clinical team.The trial aims to identy whether the participants will produce antibodies against coronavirus after being inoculated.In the first stage of the trial, just  healthy volunteers will receive the vaccine, beginning with a low dose that will gradually increase to higher doses for subsequent volunteers. This is to assess the safety of the vaccine and determine the optimal dosage.A total of  healthy volunteers are expected to be given two doses of the vaccine over the coming weeks.If it is found to be safe, and shows a promising immune response in humans, larger trials will follow later in the year.For more information on the Imperial Covid- vaccine, including how to register as a volunteer, visit the vaccine trial website.
